titleInfo.title: Novel Methods in Transcriptome-Wide Association Study

mods:mods.abstract: Genes with moderate to low expression heritability may explain a large proportion of complex trait etiology, but such genes cannot be sufficiently captured in conventional transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs), partly due to the relatively small available reference datasets for developing expression genetic prediction models to capture the moderate to low genetically regulated components of gene expression. In the first chapter, we introduce a method, the Summary-level Unified Method for Modeling Integrated Transcriptome (SUMMIT), to improve the expression prediction model accuracy and the power of TWAS by using a large expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) summary-level dataset. We apply SUMMIT to the eQTL summary-level data provided by the eQTLGen consortium. Through simulation studies and analyses of genome-wide association study summary statistics for 24 complex traits, we show that SUMMIT improves the accuracy of expression prediction in blood, successfully builds expression prediction models for genes with low expression heritability, and achieves higher statistical power than several benchmark methods. Finally, we conduct a case study of COVID-19 severity with SUMMIT and identify 11 likely causal genes associated with COVID-19 severity. In the second chapter, we introduce a method, Comprehensive omics-phenotype association estimation using \textit{Cis-} and \textit{Trans-}regulated elements (ComPACT), to integrate genetic information from \textit{trans-}loci into classic association studies, by iteratively detect potential outlying locus. Like SUMMIT, ComPACT is also capable of utilizing summary-level data to construct imputation models. However, as an extension of SUMMIT, ComPACT do not require individual-level genotype data to do model tuning. We apply ComPACT to the deCODE summary-level data and construct 233\% more imputation models than the existing method. In addition, we verify that the selected models were statistically robust by validation using an external dataset, INTERVAL, and show that our pipeline had achieved similar prediction accuracy to using individual-level data. Finally, we conduct a case study of Alzheimer's disease and identify 207 likely causal proteins, whereas competing method identify 19 likely causal proteins.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Jonathan R. Bradley, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard S. Nowakowski, University Representative; Hongyuan Cao, Committee Member; Xufeng Niu, Committee Member.
